Religious ([[Buddhism|Buddhist]] and [[Shamanism|Shamanist]]) |significance = [[New Year]] holiday |relatedto = [[Chinese New Year]], [[Japanese New Year]], [[Losar|Tibetan New Year]], [[Korean New Year]], [[Tết|Vietnamese New Year]] }} [[File:Tsagaan sar.jpg|thumb|right|290px|Tsagaan Sar meal]] The '''Mongolian Lunar New Year''', commonly known as '''Tsagaan Sar''' ({{lang-mn|Цагаан сар}}, ''Cagán sar'' / {{MongolUnicode|ᠴᠠᠭᠠᠨ}} {{MongolUnicode|ᠰᠠᠷᠠ}}, {{IPA-mn|t͡sʰaɢaːŋ sar}} or literally '''White Moon'''){{lang-bxr|Сагаан һара|''Sagán ħara''}}, {{IPA-all|sagaːŋ ħara}}; {{lang-xal|Цаһан сар|''Cahan sar''}}, {{IPA-all|t͡saɣan sar}}; {{lang-alt|Чага-Байрам}}; {{lang-sah|Үрүнь Ый|''Ürüny ıy''}}; {{lang-se|Vielgatguovssahasat}}; {{lang-iu|ᐊᐳᑦᑕᖅᑭᖅ|''Aputtaqqiq''}}; {{lang-kl|Aputqaqortoq}}, {{lang-zh|查干萨日|t=查幹薩日|p=Chágàn Sàrì}}, [[Xiao'erjing]]: {{lang|zh-Arab|ﭼَﺎقً ﺻَﺎژِ}}; [[Dungan language|Dungan]]: Санган сари, ''Sangan Sari'', is the first day of the year according to the [[Mongolian calendar|Mongolian lunisolar calendar]]. The festival of the [[Lunar New Year]] is celebrated by the [[Mongols]] along with the [[Circumpolar peoples|people of the Arctic]]. == Timing == The White Moon festival is celebrated on the first through third days of the first lunar month. Tibet's [[Losar]] occurs on the same day as the Mongolian White Moon. Tsagaan Sar is one of the most important Mongolian holidays."Tsagan Sar: The Mongolian Lunar New Year". Mongoluls. 2007. March 13, 2008.[http://mongoluls.net/tsagaansar.shtml Mongoluls.net] == Ceremony == The customs of Tsagaan Sar are significantly different depending on the region. In [[Mongolia]] around the New Year for example, families burn candles at the altar symbolizing Buddhist [[Enlightenment in Buddhism|enlightenment]]. Also people greet each other with holiday-specific greetings such as Амар байна уу? (Amar baina uu?), meaning "Are you living peacefully?"[http://sonofthemidwestinthefareast.wordpress.com/2011/02/08/амар-байна-уу-are-you-restedpeaceful/ Амар байна уу? (Are you rested/peaceful?)] Mongols also visit friends and family on this day and exchange gifts. A typical Mongol family will meet in the home dwelling of the eldest in the family.[http://www.mongoliatoday.com/issue/2/tsagaan_sar_1.html "Tsagaan Sar, the Lunar New Year"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113222017/http://www.mongoliatoday.com/issue/2/tsagaan_sar_1.html |date=2006-11-13 }} Many people will be dressed in full garment of [[Deel (clothing)|national Mongol costumes]]. When greeting their elders during the White Moon festival, Mongols perform the [[zolgokh]] greeting, grasping them by their elbows to show support for them. The eldest receives greetings from each member of the family except for his/her spouse. During the greeting ceremony, family members hold long, typically blue, silk cloths called a ''[[khadag]]''. After the ceremony, the extended family eats sheep's tail, mutton, rice with curds, dairy products, and [[buuz]]. It is also typical to drink [[Kumis|airag]] and exchange gifts. The day before Tsagaan Sar is called ''[[Dark moon|Bituun]]'', the name of the lunar phase of a new or [[dark moon]]. The lunar phases are Bituun (dark moon), Shined (new crescent moon), Tergel (full moon), and Huuchid (waxing moon). On the Bituun day, people thoroughly clean around home, herders also clean the livestock barns and shades, to meet the New Year fresh. The Bituun ceremony also includes burning candles to symbolize enlightenment of the samsara and all sentient beings and putting three pieces of ice at the doorway so that the horse of the deity [[Palden Lhamo]] could drink as the deity is believed to visit every household on this day. In the evening, families gather together—usually immediate family, in contrast to the large feast gatherings of White Moon day — and see out the old year eating dairy products and buuz. Traditionally, Mongolians settle all issues and repay all debts from the old year by this day. == Food == Depending on the region, food is prepared in a diverse array of forms. For example, the [[Mongolian cuisine|traditional food in Mongolia]] for the festival includes dairy products, rice with curds (tsagaa-цагаа) or rice with raisins (berees-бэрээс), a pyramid of traditional cookies erected on a large dish in a special fashion symbolising [[Mount Sumeru]] or [[Shambhala]] realm, a grilled side of sheep and minced beef or minced mutton steamed inside pastry, steamed dumplings known as [[buuz]], horse meat and traditional cookies.Kohn, Michael. ''[[Lonely Planet]] Mongolia''. Lonely Planet, 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-74104-578-9}}, p. 44 Tsagaan Sar is a lavish feast, requiring preparation days in advance, as the men and women make large quantities of buuz as a whole family, along with ul boov, a pastry reserved for both dessert and presentation. == During communism == During Mongolia's [[Mongolian People's Republic|Communist period]], the government banned Tsagaan Sar and tried to replace it with a holiday called "[[Agriculture in Mongolia|Collective Herder]]'s Day", but the holiday was practiced again after the [[1990 Democratic Revolution in Mongolia]].Marsh, Peter. ''The Horse-head Fiddle and the Cosmopolitan Reimagination of Tradition of Mongolia''. Routledge, 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-415-97156-0}}, p. 136 == Dates == {{outdated|date=February 2018}} The [[Mongolian calendar|Mongol calendar]] in the Tegus Buyantu (Төгсбуянт) system is a [[lunisolar calendar]]. The Tegus Buyantu astrology was developed by Mongol high priest Luvsandanzanjantsan (1639–1704), the first reincarnation of the Blama-yin Gegegen (Ламын гэгээн).Л. Тэрбиш. [[File:Vibram Five Finger Shoes.jpg|thumb|Vibram FiveFingers shoes, 2010]] '''Vibram FiveFingers''' are a type of [[minimalist shoe]] manufactured by [[Vibram]], originally marketed as a more natural alternative for different outdoors activities (sailing, kayaking, canoeing, and as a camp or after-hike shoe).<ref>{{Cite episode |title = The Living Barefoot Show episode #3: Interview to Michael Martin, National Sales Manager for Vibram FiveFingers |url = http://www.livingbarefoot.info/podcasts/LivingBarefoot_EP3.mp3 |airdate = 2009-07-30 |minutes = 47 }}</ref> The footwear is meant to replicate being barefoot and has thin, flexible soles that are contoured to the shape of the human foot, including visible individual sections for the toes.<ref name=faqs_mechanics>{{cite web |url = http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/technology/faqs_mechanics.cfm |title = Foot mechanics and health |publisher = Vibram FiveFingers |date = 2010-07-20 |accessdate = 2011-10-17 }}</ref> The company settled a lawsuit alleging false health claims and set aside $3.75 million to pay refunds of up to $94 to anyone who had purchased the product since March 21, 2009.<ref name="lawsuit"/>
== Origin == [[File:Vibram FiveFingers KSO Trek Brown.JPG |thumb|FiveFingers KSO Trek]] Invented in 1999 by Robert Fliri, a design student from [[Vinschgau]] who wanted to "figure out a way to move around in nature better." Vibram FiveFingers were developed and introduced in 2005.<ref name=faqs_mechanics/><ref>[http://bodyconsciousdesign.com/uploads/interview_fliri_for_publication.pdf "The story of the five fingers"]. Bodyconsciousdesign. 2006. Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref><ref>Dziernak, Lou (November 2009). "Barefoot your Soul". SGB. doi:1933424561. {{ISSN|1548-7407}}.</ref><ref>"Vibram FiveFingers shoes". Steve van Dulken. 2009. Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref><ref>Vonhof, John (2011). Fixing Your Feet: Prevention and Treatments for Athletes. Wilderness press. pp. 85-86. {{ISBN|978-0-89997-638-9}}.</ref><ref>"Bare facts; Running fads". The Economist. September 16, 2011. doi:2458505431.</ref>
=== Purpose === Vibram FiveFingers were originally targeted to yacht racers to maintain grip on slippery decks without compromising the barefoot experience.<ref>"Protect your feet at the beach, in the boat or at the mall with shoes designed for water and land but with more support than a water sock.". Star Tribune. June 20, 2006. doi:1064219291.</ref> Their potential use as a minimalist running shoe was suggested to the Vibram CEO by Ted McDonald, a runner who earned the nickname "Barefoot Ted" for his unshod feet and successful career as a barefoot running coach.<ref>{{cite book|last1=McDougall|first1=Christopher|title=Born To Run|date=2009|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=9780307279187|pages=163–164|edition=1st}}</ref> The purpose of these shoes as outlined by the manufacturers is to provide footwear to be mainly used for fitness, running, water sports, yoga, trekking and travelling, and other sports.<ref name=mens>"Men's Footwear." www.vibramfivefingers.com. Vibram, n.d. Web. 10 Nov 2011. <{{cite web|url=http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/products/mens_footwear.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111030424/http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/products/mens_footwear.htm |archivedate=November 11, 2011 }}>.</ref>
== Design ==
=== Styles === [[File:Vibram FiveFingers Spyridon LS Green-Grey-Black.JPG|thumb|FiveFingers Spyridon LS]] [[File:FiveFingers Bikila top view 2.jpg|thumb|FiveFingers Bikila]] Vibram FiveFingers come in a variety of styles and sizes, including FiveFingers KMD Sport, KMD Sport LS, Classic, Sprint, Flow, KSO (the most popular), TrekSport, KSO Trek, Bikila (named for [[Abebe Bikila]]), Bikila LS, Speed and also men's styles FiveFingers Spyridon, Trek LS and Bormio and women's styles FiveFingers Jaya and Jaya LR.<ref name=Womens>"Women's Footwear." www.vibramfivefingers.com. Vibram, n.d. Web. 10 Nov 2011. <{{cite web|url=http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/products/womens_footwear.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113095612/http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/products/womens_footwear.htm |archivedate=November 13, 2011 }}>.</ref> Children's KSO, Sprint and Speed styles are available.<ref>"Kid's Footwear." www.vibramfivefingers.com. Vibram, n.d. Web. 10 Nov 2011. <http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/products/kids_footwear.htm>.</ref>
=== Sizing === Unlike traditional footwear, Vibram FiveFingers do not follow the typical US or UK shoe-sizing scales.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} They require precise foot length measurement with accuracy of 1/8 inch (3 mm) and conversion to the FiveFingers sizing chart. This ranges from 38–50 for men, 34–42 for women, and 29–36 for children. As a result, the shoe sizing more closely mirrors the EU system. However, minor discrepancies exist between the women's and men's sizing, so, ''e.g.'', a women's size 39 does not equal a men's size 39.<ref>"Size Conversion Chart." www.vibramfivefingers.com. Vibram, n.d. Web. 10 Nov 2011. <{{cite web|url=http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/size_fit/size_conversion_chart.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115083803/http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/size_fit/size_conversion_chart.htm |archivedate=November 15, 2011 }}>.</ref>
=== Materials === Vibram FiveFingers comprise many different materials that vary depending on the style of shoe. The most common components are Vibram TC-1 performance rubber, which makes up the sole of these shoes, a thin stretch polyamide comprising the frame of the shoe that molds to the contours of the user's foot, and an antimicrobial microfiber footbed.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
== Minimalist shoes == In a report on an article in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', co-author Daniel E. Lieberman stated that "People who wear conventional running shoes tend to run with a significantly different [[Foot strike (gait)#Foot strike|strike]] than those who run in minimalist shoes or barefoot. By landing on the middle or front of the foot, barefoot runners have almost no impact collision."<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/01/100127134241.htm |title = Barefoot running: How humans ran comfortably and safely before the invention of shoes |publisher = Sciencedaily.com |date = 2010-02-01 |access-date = 2011-10-17 }}</ref> Lieberman et al.'s study was an experiment that involved five groups of runners from [[Kenya]] and the [[United States]]. The two American groups were adult athletes who had run with shoes since childhood, and those who habitually [[barefoot running|ran barefoot]] or with minimal footwear such as Vibram FiveFingers (mentioned by name in the study). The three Kenyan groups were adults who had never run in shoes until late adolescence, as well as two teenage groups: those that habitually wore shoes and those that always ran barefoot. The runners were instructed to run over a [[force plate]] that was embedded in a 25-meter track, and were recorded during the run using a three-dimensional infrared kinematic system. These measurements were used to assess the pattern with which the foot strikes the ground and how forcibly it does so.<ref name=Lieberman>{{Cite journal |last1 = Lieberman |first1 = DE. |last2 = Venkadesan |first2 = M. |last3 = Werbel |first3 = WA. |last4 = Daoud |first4 = AI. |last5 = D'Andrea |first5 = S. |last6 = Davis |first6 = IS. |last7 = Mang'eni |first7 = RO. |last8 = Pitsiladis |first8 = Y. |title = Foot strike patterns and collision forces in habitually barefoot versus shod runners. |journal = Nature |volume = 463 |issue = 7280 |pages = 531–5 |date=Jan 2010 |doi = 10.1038/nature08723 |pmid = 20111000 |bibcode = 2010Natur.463..531L }}</ref> [[File:Toe socks + toe shoes.jpg|thumb|FiveFingers with toe socks]]
=== Health effects === [[Barefoot running]], which is similar to running with FiveFingers on, appears to decrease the risk of ankle sprain and [[plantar fasciitis]].<ref name=sportsci>Warburton, Michael. "Barefoot Running may help keep runners on their feet." Sportscience. (2001): n. page. Web. 10 Nov. 2011. <http://www.sportsci.org/jour/0103/mw.htm></ref> Because the Fivefingers lack any support or cushioning (or very minimal at most), the intent is to allow the wearer to engage a natural footstrike, as if he/she would run barefoot. Incorrect, unnatural running forms, especially where a heelstrike is involved, results in the same uncomfortable or painful feedback as when running barefoot, therefore leading the wearer to adjust the stride. This feedback is said to be filtered out of common running shoes because of the thick sole, therefore leading to possible injuries.
If not conditioned slowly enough, especially when transitioning away from heelstrike running or from wearing shoes with an elevated heel, the sole of the foot or [[plantar fascia]] can become inflamed or damaged with activity.<ref name=Lieberman/> Also due to over-training or incorrect form, runners may experience Achilles tendonitis or metatarsal inflammation and fractures. Over-striding in Vibram FiveFingers, that is, landing with the foot too far in front of one's hips, adds extra unnecessary stress to the calf muscles, Achilles tendon, and the arch of the foot, which can lead to serious health problems if not addressed.<ref name=Lieberman/>
One study found a greater number of new wearers of FiveFingers showed an increase in bone marrow [[edema]] than those in the study's control group.<ref>http://unique-sportstime.de/site/wp-content/uploads/Barfuss-Laufen1.pdf</ref> It recommended transition to use of the shoe be very slow and gradual.
===Lawsuit=== In 2012, an initial lawsuit was filed against Vibram over claims made about their FiveFingers minimalist shoe. Vibram claimed that the shoe "reduce[s] foot injuries and strengthen[s] foot muscles". While Vibram has "expressly" denied "any actual or potential fault ... or liability", on May 7, 2014 it was announced that company has moved to settle the suit and agreed to set aside $3.75 million to pay refunds of up to $94 to anyone who had purchased the product since March 21, 2009.<ref name="lawsuit">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2014/05/08/say-it-aint-so-vibram-say-it-aint-so/?tid=hpModule_1f58c93a-8a7a-11e2-98d9-3012c1cd8d1e|title=People who bought these Vibram FiveFinger shoes may be entitled to a refund|author=Lenny Bernstein|publisher=Washington Post|date=May 8, 2014|access-date=May 8, 2014}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Jika-tabi]] *[[Minimalist shoe]] *[[Toe socks]] *[[Tabi]] *[[Vivobarefoot]] *[[Xero Shoes]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == {{commons category|FiveFingers shoes}} * {{official website|http://www.vibramfivefingers.com/}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8483401.stm Have Shoes Changed the Way We Run?] * [http://sportsscientists.com/2014/05/vibram-lawsuit-barefoot-running-common-sense/ ''The Vibram lawsuit, barefoot running and science perspectives'', The Science of Sport]

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Wonder Showzen | image = Wonder showzen.png | show_name_2 = ''Kids Show'' | genre = [[Puppetry]], [[Black comedy]], [[Horror fiction|Horror]], [[Adult animation]], [[Satire]], [[Sketch comedy]], [[Surreal humor]], [[Post-modern]], [[Toilet humor]], [[Off-color humor]] | creator = {{Plainlist | * [[Vernon Chatman]] * [[John Lee (producer)|John Lee]] }} | based_on = | developer = {{Plainlist | * Vernon Chatman * John Lee }} | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = {{Plainlist | * Vernon Chatman * John Lee * Alyson Levy * [[Jim Tozzi (PFFR)|Jim Tozzi]] }} | judges = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = "Old Theme" by [[PFFR]] | endtheme = "Goodbye Song" by PFFR | composer = Chris Anderson | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 16 (and 1 pilot) | list_episodes = List of Wonder Showzen episodes | executive_producer = {{Plainlist | * Vernon Chatman * John Lee }} | producer = Jessica Vitkus | editor = | location = New York City, New York, U.S. | cinematography = John Tanzer | camera = [[Multiple-camera setup|Multi-camera]] | runtime = 21–23 minutes | company = {{Plainlist | * Raw Power Productions (episode 1) * [[Augenblick Studios]] * [[PFFR#PFFR Productions|PFFR Productions]] * [[MTV|MTV Production Development]] }} | distributor = [[MTV]] | channel = [[MTV2]] | picture_format = [[NTSC]] | audio_format = [[Stereophonic sound|Stereophonic]] | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|2005|3|11}} | last_aired = {{End date|2006|5|19}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.mtv.com/shows/wonder_showzen/series.jhtml | website_title = Wonder Showzen | production_website = http://www.pffr.net/ }} '''''Wonder Showzen''''' is an [[United States|American]] [[sketch comedy]] [[television series]] that aired between 2005 and 2006 on [[MTV2]]. It was created by [[John Lee (producer)|John Lee]] and [[Vernon Chatman]] of [[PFFR]]. Described as a children’s show for adults, the show's format is a parody of educational [[PBS]] children's television shows such as ''[[Sesame Street]]'' and ''[[The Electric Company]]'' (e.g. use of [[stock footage]], [[puppetry]], and clips of children being interviewed), parodying the format with adult-oriented content. In addition to general controversial comedy, it [[satire|satirizes]] [[politics]], [[religion]], [[war]], [[sex]] and [[culture]] with [[black comedy]]. Every episode begins with a disclaimer, which reads: "''Wonder Showzen'' contains offensive, despicable content that is too controversial and too awesome for actual children. The stark, ugly and profound truths ''Wonder Showzen'' exposes may be soul-crushing to the weak of spirit. If you allow a child to watch this show, you are a bad parent or guardian." ==Development== ''Wonder Showzen'' was created by [[John Lee (producer)|John Lee]] and [[Vernon Chatman]], who pitched to the [[USA Network]] in 2000, but after a few minutes of viewing, executives there quickly concluded it did not fit the network's programming style.''New York Daily News'': [http://www.nydailynews.com/04-27-2005/entertainment/story/303787p-260006c.html "'Wonder' shock-ful of adult humor"]. Retrieved December 13, 2006. However, [[Viacom]] was re-branding MTV2 and made ''Wonder Showzen'' part of its new programming lineup. It aired as part of Sic 'Em Fridays, along with ''[[Dirty Sanchez (TV series)|Dirty Sanchez]]'' and ''[[Wildboyz]]''. The pilot was named simply "Kids Show". The ''Wonder Showzen'' theme song is still 'Kids Show'. Reruns of the show also aired on MTV and [[Comedy Central]].{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} MTV released the first season of ''Wonder Showzen'' on DVD March 28, 2006. The second season of Wonder Showzen premiered on March 31, 2006 and had its season-two finale starring Clarence on May 19, 2006 on MTV2. This season was released on DVD October 10, 2006, with an [[Easter egg (media)|easter egg]] that featured an animation contest. The grand prize was announced as the winner's animation appearing on "the next DVD", but the creators later said a third season was unlikely,[http://www.tvsquad.com/2006/10/18/a-third-season-of-wonder-showzen-is-unlikely TVSquad.com] and MTV afterward canceled the show. A return is even more unlikely as the creators of ''Wonder Showzen'' went on to produce the animated series ''[[Xavier: Renegade Angel]]''. It aired in Canada on [[MTV2 (Canada)|MTV2]], the United Kingdom and [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] on [[MTV Rocks|MTV Two]], [[MTV (UK and Ireland)|MTV]] and [[TMF (UK & Ireland)|TMF]], Australia on [[MTV Australia|MTV]], Germany and Italy on MTV Entertainment, [[Latin America]] on [[MTV Latin America]] and in the Baltics on [[MTV Networks Baltic]]. ==Characters== {{main article|List of Wonder Showzen characters}} ==Cast== ===Adults=== * [[Vernon Chatman]] (Chauncey/Clarence/Various Voices) * [[John Lee (PFFR)|John Lee]] (Wordsworth/Him/Various Voices) * Alyson Levy (Sthugar/Various Voices) * [[Jim Tozzi (PFFR)|Jim Tozzi]] (Various Voices) ===Kids=== * [[Benjamin Krueger]] * Evan Seligman * Taylor Bedlivy * P.J. Connaire * [[Jacob Kogan]] * Michael Samms * Trevor Heins * Miles Kath * Jasmina Lee * Dominic Payer * Mike Gibbons * Alexandra Rose * Frankie Scapoli * Ryan Soos * Brianna Simpkins * Miles Williams * Pierce Gidez * Madison Rose * Ameerah Moore * Ryan Simpkins ===Cameos=== ====Season One==== *[[Jon Glaser]] – As Mr. Story in episode 101. *[[Flavor Flav]] – As himself in episode 101, The full "Storytime with Flavor Flav" was cut from the broadcast version of the episode. It still appears however on the Season One DVD. *[[Dick Gregory]] – As Mr. Sun in episode 103. *[[Amy Sedaris]] – As Miss Amy in episode 106. *[[Christopher Meloni]] – As the Cooties Spokesman in episode 107. *Chris Anderson – As Koby Teeth in episode 104 *Madison Rose - As herself in episodes 106 ("History") and 109 ("Patience") ====Season Two==== *[[David Cross]] – As T-Totaled Timbo in episode 203, Hostage in episode 206, and Junkyard Jessip in episode 207. *[[Judah Friedlander]] – As Crickey in episodes 203 and 207. *[[Jon Glaser]] – As Dr. Rawstein in episodes 203 and 207. *Darlene Violette – As Bettsy Beth Bethanie in episodes 203 and 207. *[[Amy Poehler]] – As Miss Mary in episodes 203 and 206. *[[John Oates]] – As himself, singing in the song, "War doesn't solve anything" in episode 206. *[[Devendra Banhart]] – As himself, singing in the song, "War doesn't solve anything" in episode 206. *[[Rick Springfield]] – As himself, singing in the song, "War doesn't solve anything" in episode 206. *[[Corin Tucker]] – As herself, singing in the song, "War doesn't solve anything" in episode 206. *[[Todd Barry]] – As Barold Q. Mosley in episode 207. *[[Zach Galifianakis]] – As Uncle Daddy in episode 207. *[[Will Oldham]] – As Pastor Pigmeat in episode 207. *[[Heather Lawless]] – As Permanently Pregnant Peggy in episode 203 and 207. *Barbara Ann Davison – As Cousin Grandma Pervis in episode 203 and 207. *Chris Anderson – As Mr. Corn in episode 203 ==Recurring segments== * '''Beat Kids''' – One of the children, most often Trevor, leads a journalistic segment with mostly offensive, humorous questions, ridiculing interviewees at a given venue. The segment appears in almost every episode. * '''What's Jim Drawing?''' – Appeared in episode 202 and 206. * '''Horse Apples''' – A segment in episode 203, which later expanded into an entire episode in 207, that parodies ''[[Hee Haw]]'' and [[Blue Collar Comedy|redneck comedy]]. The latter episode featured several guest actors. * '''Funny/Not Funny''' – A series of clips, often depicting violent or macabre images, airs with a chorus of children saying either "funny" or "not funny". * '''So Now You Know''' – A parody of "[[The More You Know]]", Where kids say questions and a computer shows their answers. It appeared twice on season one and once on season two in episode 205. * '''Q&A''' – A series of children each answer a single question. * '''Breaking News''' – Features the news reporter. * '''We Went To...''' – Children narrate an ostensibly educational trip while old stock film airs. * '''Clarence's Movies''' – Clarence the puppet interviews people on the street on a common theme, usually antagonistically or obnoxiously, which is often reciprocated by violence or threats. * '''Story Time''' – A special guest reads a story to the children. Guests have included [[Flavor Flav]] (as himself although it was unaired), [[Jon Glaser]] (as Mr. Story), [[David Cross]] (as a hostage), and [[Amy Sedaris]] (as Ms. Amy). * '''Mr. Body''' – A cartoon segment that parodies the [[Slim Goodbody]] character from the [[Captain Kangaroo]] television series. * '''D.O.G.O.B.G.Y.N''' – A cartoon chronicling a dog with the ability to aid in child birth; part of the title derives from a short form for "[[obstetrics and gynaecology]]", and part of it comes from the common domesticated [[dog]]. * '''Tyler, America's Most Perfect Child''' – A young [[non-binary]] child with a disturbingly well-mannered demeanor, who often forms statements about how perfect, wonderful and special they are. ==Series overview== {{Series overview | color0S = #FFFF00 | link0S = #Early Concept | linkT0S = {{abbr|Concept|Early Concept}} | start0S = Unaired | end0S = | color0SS = #00FF00 | link0SS = #Pilot | linkT0SS = Pilot | start0SS = Unaired | end0SS = | color1 = #4DBCF2 | link1 = #Season 1 (2005) | episodes1 = 8 | start1 = {{Start date|2005|3|11}} | end1 = {{End date|2005|4|29}} | color2 = #FF5F5F | link2 = #Season 2 (2015) | episodes2 = 8 | start2 = {{Start date|2006|3|31}} | end2 = {{End date|2006|5|19}} }} ==Episodes== ===Early Concept=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; background:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#FFFF00"| Title ! style="background:#FFFF00; width:110px"| Air date {{Episode list |Title=Early Concept |OriginalAirDate=Unaired for US |ShortSummary=The 8-minute tape was made for fun in 1999 by PFFR, and they shopped it around different stores. The USA Network eventually saw their tape, and gave them money and six months to make a pilot episode. |LineColor=#FFFF00 }} |} ===Pilot episode=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; background:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#00FF00"| Title ! style="background:#00FF00; width:110px"| Air date {{Episode list |Title=Kids Show |OriginalAirDate=Unaired for US |ShortSummary=Unaired pilot episode produced in 2000 for the [[USA Network]]. The Letter N becomes depressed and self-loathing and goes on a quest to find herself. |LineColor=00FF00 }} |} ===Season 1: 2005=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; background:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#4DBCF2; width:30px"| Nº ! style="background:#4DBCF2"| Title ! style="background:#4DBCF2; width:110px"| Air date {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=101 |Title=Birth |Cartoons=D.o.g.o.b.g.y.n. |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|3|11}} |ShortSummary=Altered version of the pilot episode. The gang tries to help out the depressed Letter N. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=102 |Title=Space |Cartoons=Segregation |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|3|18}} |ShortSummary=Chauncey and his friend Kaitlin go into outer space. They confront God after the Earth is destroyed during their trip. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=103 |Title=Ocean |Cartoons=Mr. Bible |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|3|25}} |ShortSummary=The gang go on a quest to find a bottle of pure liquid Imagination. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=104 |Title=Diversity |Cartoons=Hobo Ops |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|4|1}} |ShortSummary=Letters and Numbers have a war over who is better, while two members of the schism fall in love. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=105 |Title=Nature |Cartoons=Global Politics in 30 Seconds |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|4|8}} |ShortSummary=Chauncey must save the day when [[Mother Nature]] gets a sex change operation. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=106 |Title=History |Cartoons=Boogie Noogie Bunch |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|4|15}} |ShortSummary=Number 2 comes to visit the gang in Number 1's place and becomes suicidal when no one likes her. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=107 |Title=Health |Cartoons=Jimagination |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|4|22}} |ShortSummary=When Wordsworth comes down with a case of the cooties, Him uses it to his advantage and sells Wordsworth's encrusted sores as snack treats. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=108 |Title=Patience |Cartoons=Punk Mark |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2005|4|29}} |ShortSummary=Season 1 Finale. An episode which tries the viewer's patience, consisting of a first act, and then after realizing how little sense the first act made, the first act in reverse to "literally undo any damage [this episode] may have caused", and then a third act occurring quickly, about speed. |LineColor=4DBCF2 }} |} ===Season 2: 2006=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; background:#FFFFFF" ! style="background:#FF5F5F; width:30px"| Nº ! style="background:#FF5F5F"| Title ! style="background:#FF5F5F; width:110px"| Air date {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 201 |Title=Body |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|3|31}} |ShortSummary=The gang convinces the overweight Letter P to get [[liposuction]]. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 202 |Title=Time |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|4|7}} |ShortSummary=Chauncey's future self from two minutes into the future causes havoc for Chauncey in the present time. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 203 |Title=Knowledge |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|4|14}} |ShortSummary=Middle America visits the show and the gang falls in love with his Stupid. They let him take over Wonder Showzen, turning it into "Horse Apples." (First episode that has two "Beat Kids" segments). |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 204 |Title=Justice |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|4|21}} |ShortSummary=The gang revisits the old days of America with slavery. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 205 |Title=Science |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|4|28}} |ShortSummary=Chauncey and Him climb into Wordsworth's brain to help him face his fears and become a man. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 206 |Title=Cooperation |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|5|5}} |ShortSummary=The gang goes to war with a bootleg version of ''Wonder Showzen''. The "peace settlement" is that the show be divided 60-40, thus the final act has several separate bits with full sound going on at the same time, which caps with an apocalyptic explosion; This is the last we see of all the main cast, except the news anchor and Clarence. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 207 |Title=Mathematics |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|5|12}} |ShortSummary=An entire episode of "Horse Apples" instead of the episode originally shown in previews for this week. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 208 |Title=The Clarence Special Report on Compelling Television |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2006|5|19}} |ShortSummary=Season 2 Finale/Series Finale. Clarence challenges [[New York City|New Yorkers]] to produce compelling television. At the end, he finds out there's no such thing, skydives off a helicopter, and drowns himself in the ocean. |LineColor=FF5F5F }} |} ==Reception== [[Matt Groening]], creator of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' and ''[[Futurama]]'' said "Wonder Showzen is so weirdly funny the top of your head will burst and your skull will fly out."''The Futon Critic'': [http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2006/02/27/mtv2-announces-the-triumphant-return-of-wonder-showzen-and-the-andy-milonakis-show-to-sic-em-fridays-with-fresh-new-episodes-starting-on-march-31st-at-9pm-et-pt--20674/20060227mtv201/ MTV2 Announces the Triumphant Return of 'Wonder Showzen' and 'The Andy Milonakis Show' to Sic 'Em Fridays with Fresh New Episodes Starting on March 31st at 9pm ET/PT].
